quoteFirst: School lasts only about three-quarters of an hour at a time.  Dinner always at two.  Lock-up at night varies from five to a
quoteLast: .  We have supper at nine, and go to bed at ten.  So you see, in the natural order of events, we have no very overpoweringly hard work.
title: Foxholme Hall, and Other Tales
author: Kingston, William Henry Giles, 1814-1880

quoteFirst: “At about
quoteLast: the officer of the deck on board the unfortunate vessel discovered something about 100 yards away, moving along the water. It came directly towards the ship, and within two minutes of the time it was first sighted was alongside. The cable was slipped, the engines backed, and all hands called to quarters. But it was too late—the torpedo struck the _Housatonic_ just forward of the mainmast, on the starboard side, in a line with the magazine.
title: Submarine Warfare, Past, Present, and Future
author: Fyfe, Herbert C.; Fremantle, E. R. Sir, 1836-1929 [Author of introduction, etc.]; Reed, Edward J. (Edward James), Sir, 1830-1906 [Contributor]

quoteFirst: Several times she requested to know the hour, saying that although her mamma had given her permission to remain until ten o'clock, she should certainly return to her at nine. She inquired again at half-past eight, and again at a
quoteLast: . During this time, Cecilia, without being observed, had two or three times raised her eyes to the clock. A minute before nine she rang the bell; her mother asked her why she did so.
title: Moral Tales
author: Guizot, Madame (Elisabeth Charlotte Pauline), 1773-1827; Burke, L., Mrs. [Translator]

quoteFirst: They had formed a work club consisting only of themselves, and it was to meet for the first time this morning. In order to ensure the success of the first meeting they had had a heavy breakfast at a
quoteLast: , because, as Reggie said, brain work is more exhausting than anything else, after which they had played a little snob-cricket in the archway between the two halves of Fellows’ Buildings, in order to clear the brain, until their names were taken by the porter and entered in the report book.
title: The Babe, B.A. : being the uneventful history of a young gentleman at Cambridge University
author: Benson, E. F. (Edward Frederic), 1867-1940

quoteFirst: “And talking of posting that parcel, I must just make a diversion to tell you something really interesting. For all I know to the contrary, I might have seen the murderer with my own eyes, in the very act of posting it! As it happened, I was passing through Southampton Street that evening at just about a
quoteLast: . Little did I guess, as Mr. Edgar Wallace would say, that the first act of this tragic drama was possibly being unfolded at that very minute under my unsuspecting nose.
title: The poisoned chocolates case
author: Berkeley, Anthony, 1893-1971

quoteFirst: When the trays reappeared with biscuits and wine, punctually at a
quoteLast: , there was conversation, comparing of cards, and talking over tricks; but by-and-by Captain Brown sported a bit of literature.

quoteFirst: "Oh, hush, you're the most disagreeable person! I wish Lila hadn't gone home. Well, she did just that. She said the artistic temperament was no excuse for discourteous falsehood--or she almost the same as said it--meaning breaking your word, you know, for Sara had promised she would come at eight, and there it was
quoteLast: . She said that it might be wiser next time to invite somebody more reliable about keeping engagements. Sara did not answer a word--only went white as a sheet and walked out of the room.
title: Beatrice Leigh at College: A Story for Girls
author: Schwartz, Julia Augusta, 1873-1957; Nagel, Eva M., 1880- [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: We found the trenches much improved as regards water, but still in need of most urgent attention to prevent a complete collapse of all breastworks. Except for one or two angry bursts on Tissage Dump, the enemy was exceedingly quiet; and at
quoteLast: on February 14th, the first anniversary of our departure for France, we handed over to the 13th Welch and said good-bye to Houplines. Of the many men who served with the battalion, few, if any, will look back on Houplines without some feeling akin to affection.
title: The History of the 2/6th (Rifle) Battalion, "the King's" (Liverpool Regiment) 1914-1919
author: Wurtzburg, C. E. (Charles Edward), 1891-1952

quoteLast: , having risen and dressed with decorum, and at the hour when a normal Christian should.

quoteFirst: Nicholas Hotel, in Broadway, where they engaged rooms; but Fogg was the only one who slept. Next day was the 12th of December. From that day, at seven in the morning, to the 21st, at a
quoteTime: quarter to nine in the evening
quoteLast: , was a period of nine days, thirteen hours, and forty-five minutes; so if Phileas Fogg had sailed in the _China_, he would have reached London in time to win his wager.

quoteLast: !" he said. "He has fifteen minutes in which to make good his bluff. But I do not fear interruption.

quoteFirst: _26th June._—Pul Karriud to Zuháb, thirty-two miles. We left Karriud at
quoteLast: yesterday, and proceeded W.N.W. through a narrow valley, rising gently for eight miles. Here we descended by a rocky path into a deep winding defile, the sides of which are thickly covered with oak-trees.
title: From the Indus to the Tigris
author: Bellew, H. W. (Henry Walter), 1834-1892

quoteFirst: The _Calliope_ was the nearest in; she had the _Vandalia_ close on her port side and a little ahead, the _Olga_ close a-starboard, the reef under her heel; and steaming and veering on her cables, the unhappy ship fenced with her three dangers.  About a
quoteLast: she carried away the _Vandalia's_ quarter gallery with her jib-boom; a moment later, the _Olga_ had near rammed her from the other side.  By nine the _Vandalia_ dropped down on her too fast to be avoided, and clapped her stern under the bowsprit of the English ship, the fastenings of which were burst asunder as she rose.
title: A Footnote to History: Eight Years of Trouble in Samoa
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis, 1850-1894

quoteFirst: 55, “five minutes with the daily news;” 9 a.m., class work begins; 12, class work closes; 12.15 p.m., dinner; 1 p.m., work bell; 1.30 p.m., class work begins; 3.30 p.m., class work ends; 5.30 p.m., bell to “knock off” work; 6 p.m., supper; 7.10 p.m., evening prayers; 7.30 p.m., evening study hours;
quoteLast: , evening study hour closes; 9.20 p.m., warning retiring bell; 9.30 p.m., retiring bell.
title: Up from Slavery: An Autobiography

quoteLast: Sunday evening soon! Your bold, your beautiful,

quoteFirst: He had been walking there for three-quarters of an hour, passing many carriages; but not one of them was standing at the place designated. At last, about a
quoteLast: , a cab coming from the Barrière de l'Etoile stopped in front of the entrance. Chamoureau instantly drew near and walked around it; the curtains were lowered, which fact convinced him that his inamorata was inside.

quoteFirst: In this way one may come to exist as in a prison, and one's life may cease to be one's own.  One may take the dog out for a walk at eight o'clock, and meditate the whole time on the fact that one must begin to read at a
quoteLast: , and that one must not be late.

quoteFirst: This morning I came away at a
quoteLast: : a hard frost. To-day I have seen Norton, and called on Charles Sumner. To-morrow I am to dine with Norton, to meet Felton, the Greek Professor, at the Club; and the next day at his father’s, and to call on Longfellow, who called on me.
title: Prose remains of Arthur Hugh Clough, with a selection from his letters and a memoir
